# Metric Construction


## Definition & Interpretation


$$Government\: Grants\:Ratio = \frac{Government \: Grant \: Revenue}{Total \: Revenues} $$

The government grants ratio measures the percentage of an organizationâ€™s revenues that come from government grants and contributions. 

High values in this ratio indicate that more of an organization's revenues come from government grants while a lower number indicates that an organization's funds come from other donation sources (private foundations), earned income, or investment income.


## Variables 

Note: This data is available only for organizations that filed 990s using e-file submissions. The data is sourced from AWS. 

* **Numerator:** Government Grant Contributions (Revenue)
  <br>
  
  *	On 990: PART 9, LINE 25(C)
    - AWS Tax File Data: F9_08_REV_CONTR_GOVT_GRANT
    <br>
  
  *	On EZ: Not Available
    - AWS Tax File Data: Not Available
  <br>
* **Denominator:** Total Revenues
  *	On 990: PART 8, LINE 12(A)
    -AWS Tax File Data: F9_08_REV_TOT_TOT
    
  *	On EZ: PART 1, Line 9
    -AWS Tax File Data: F9_01_REV_TOT_CY
  <br>




```{r, eval=T}


# TEMPORARY VARIABLES 
govgrants  <- core$F9_08_REV_CONTR_GOVT_GRANT
total_rev <- core$F9_08_REV_TOT_TOT

# can't divide by zero
total_expense[ total_expense == 0 ] <- NA

# SAVE RESULTS 
core$gov_grant_ratio <-  govgrants / total_expense
                     
# summary( core$gov_grant_ratio )
```


## Standardize Scales

Check high and low values to see what makes sense. 

```{r, fig.height=4}
x.05 <- quantile( core$gov_grant_ratio, 0.05, na.rm=T )
x.95 <- quantile( core$gov_grant_ratio, 0.95, na.rm=T )

ggplot( core, aes(x = gov_grant_ratio ) ) +  
  geom_density( alpha = 0.5) + 
  xlim( x.05, x.95 ) 
```




```{r}
core2 <- core

# proportion of values that are negative
#mean( core2$gov_grant_ratio < 0, na.rm=T ) 
#core2$gov_grant_ratio[ core2$gov_grant_ratio < 0 ] <- 0

# proption of values above 200% 
#mean( core2$gov_grant_ratio > 50, na.rm=T ) 
#core2$gov_grant_ratio[ core2$gov_grant_ratio > 50 ] <- 50



x.05 <- quantile( core$gov_grant_ratio, 0.05, na.rm=T )
x.95 <- quantile( core$gov_grant_ratio, 0.95, na.rm=T )

core2 <- core

# proportion of values that are negative
# mean( core2$der < 0, na.rm=T ) 

# proption of values above 1% 
# mean( core2$der > 5, na.rm=T ) 

# WINSORIZATION AT 5th and 95th PERCENTILES

core2$gov_grant_ratio[ core2$gov_grant_ratio < x.05 ] <- x.05
core2$gov_grant_ratio[ core2$gov_grant_ratio > x.95 ] <- x.95
```



## Metric Scope


Tax data is available for full 990 filers and 990EZ filers (organizations with Gross receipts < $200,000 and Total assets < $500,000). 

The data have been capped to those with values between 5% and 95% of the normal distribution to cut off outliers and exempt organizations with zero profitability (though negative values are allowed still). 



# Descriptive Statistics


Note: All monetary variables have been converted to thousands of dollars. 

```{r, results="asis"}

core2 %>%
  mutate( # gov_grant_ratio = gov_grant_ratio * 10000,
    totrevenue = totrevenue / 1000,
    totfuncexpns = totfuncexpns / 1000, 
    lndbldgsequipend = lndbldgsequipend / 1000,
    totassetsend = totassetsend / 1000,
    totliabend = totliabend / 1000,
    totnetassetend = totnetassetend / 1000 ) %>% 
  select( STATE,  NTEE1, NTMAJ12, 
          gov_grant_ratio, 
          AGE, 
          totrevenue, totfuncexpns, 
          lndbldgsequipend, totassetsend, 
          totnetassetend, totliabend ) %>%

  stargazer( type = s.type, 
             digits=2, 
             summary.stat = c("min","p25","median",
                              "mean","p75","max", "sd"),
             covariate.labels = c("Government Grants Ratio", "Age", 
                                  "Revenue ($1k)", "Expenses($1k)", 
                                  "Buildings ($1k)", "Total Assets ($1k)",
                                  "Net Assets ($1k)", "Liabiliies ($1k)"))
```



What proportion of orgs have Government Grants ratios equal to zero?


```{r}
prop.zero <- mean( core2$gov_grant_ratio == 0, na.rm=T )
```


In the sample, `r 100*round(prop.zero,2)` percent of the organizations have Government Grants ratios equal to zero, meaning they have no Government Grantss. These organizations are dropped from subsequent graphs to keep the visualizations clean. The interpretation of the graphics should be the distributions of Government Grants ratios for organizations that have positive or negative values.  




```{r}
###
### ADD QUANTILES
###
###   function create_quantiles() defined in r-functions.R

core2$exp.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totfuncexpns,   n.groups=5 )
core2$rev.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totrevenue,     n.groups=5 )
core2$asset.q <- create_quantiles( var=core2$totnetassetend, n.groups=5 )
core2$age.q   <- create_quantiles( var=core2$AGE,            n.groups=5 )
core2$land.q <- create_quantiles(var=core2$lndbldgsequipend,            n.groups=5 )

```
